prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Equity is probably the most common basis for awarding a remedy for breach of confidential business information. The concept of trust is one of the oldest bases for the protection of confidential information. The Statute of Uses, 1535,[1] for example, was framed in terms of “use, confidence or trust”, and a couplet attributed to Sir Thomas More, Lord Chancellor, provides that: “Three things are to be held in conscience; Fraud, Accident, and things of Confidence.”
The concept of trust was also used in the Millar v. Taylor[2] decision. Willes J. held that:

Most certainly, the sole proprietor of any copy may determine whether he will print it, or not. If any person takes it to the press without his consent, he is certainly a trespasser; though he came by it by legal means, as by loan or by devolution; for, he transgresses the bounds of his trust; and therefore is a trespasser.
Professor A.W. Scott, in his treatise, the Law of Trusts,[3] observed that for over 100 years, the courts in the United States have held that:

… where an intentional converter of property acquires other property in exchange for it, the owner of the property not only is entitled to enforce an equitable lien upon the product but he may charge the converter as constructive trustee of the product [This] is a salutary rule which should have some deterrent effect upon those who would meddle with the property of others … It would seem sufficient to impose upon him a liability for the value of the property which he converted, and to permit the owner of the property converted, to enforce an equitable lien upon the product to secure his claim against the convertor.

The source of the duty of good faith is the property right in the information itself, and the “owner of the property” as such acquires an “equitable lien”. Even where there is no express or implied covenant regulating an employee's position (or where there is a covenant which amounts to an invalid restraint of trade), the employee is held to owe an equitable duty of good faith, arising out of the contract of employment, not to use or disclose the employer's trade secrets during or after the termination of his or her employment.[4]

The equity to be protected is that described by Lord Denning in the case of Seager v. Copydex Ltd.[5] when he said that “he who has received information in confidence shall not take unfair advantage of it”. This theory has been applied both to confidential business information and to unpatented inventions. Lord Denning's view was accepted in Canada in the Slavutych decision.[6]
In the decision of LAC Minerals,[7] La Forest J. for the majority held that:

The essence of the imposition of fiduciary obligations [like the essence of the protection of confidences], is its utility in the promotion and preservation of desired social behaviour and institutions … In the modern world the exchange of confidential information is both necessary and expected. Evidence of an accepted business morality in the mining industry was given by the defendant, and the Court of Appeal found that the practice was not only reasonable, but that it would foster the exploration and development of our natural resources. The institution of bargaining in good faith is one that is worthy of legal protection in those circumstances where that protection accords with the expectations of the parties.

The LAC decision is particularly important as it expressly endorses the view that a breach of confidential business information is subject to a constructive trust in favour of the owner of the information because the information was imparted in confidence.

In Vantage Point, Inc. v. Parker Bros.,[8] the plaintiff was granted relief as a result of the “undue advantage through unfair conduct [or] reprehensible means of obtaining the valuable property rights of another without compensation”.

Even where an obligation exists in contract, many common law courts have found a common law duty to act in good faith and not to make use of confidential information independently of the employment contract.[9] In A.B. Consolidated Ltd. v. Europe Strength Food Co. Pty. Ltd.,[10] Woodhouse J. for the majority held that the obligations of confidence, which in that case consisted of using a manufacturing process which had been disclosed during unsuccessful negotiations for a licensing agreement, “are founded in equity and arise quite independently of contract or of tort”. Similarly, the court in Werlin v. Reader's Digest Ass'n,[11] held that:

Even if the plaintiff has no property right in an idea, and even though no express or implied-in-fact contract for the sale or use of such an idea has been established, the defendant may, in appropriate circumstances … be found liable to the plaintiff in quasi-contract on a theory of unjust enrichment.

However, in order to invoke the equitable principles of unjust enrichment in the United States, the idea must be novel, original and concrete.[12] Quebec courts have also favoured the common law approach to characterize a situation as one imposing a fiduciary obligation rather than enforcing the contract as is frequently done in the French courts.[13]
